30 Days of ASP.NET:Adding Style06 Jan 2012

I realize there are people who would disagree, but I largely discourage heavy use of the Visual Web Developer 2010 Express CSS tools. They are largely cumbersome, and becoming fluent in CSS and understanding how to include style sheets in your ASP documents will not only suffice, it will give you greater speed and control. That being said, I am going to look at adding some basic styles to the simple page created in the last series entry.

Adding a Style Sheet to a Project

By now you should have a pretty good grasp of how things are added to a project. Right click the project name in the solution explorer and choose "Add New Item".

Attaching a Style Sheet to the Document

The easiest way to do this is to drag the style sheet from the solution explorer into the document. This will create the link element with all the appropriate attributes. You can also do what web developers have been doing for ages and type it out your self into the head section of your document. 
<link href="styles.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text.css" media="all" />
It is worth mentioning the "Apply Styles" and "Manage Styles" panels. These are pretty useful for getting an overview of present selectors and styles, as well as copying inline styles over to external style sheets. I will demonstrate how you can focus on attaching an external style sheet to the document with these panels. Click View > Manage Styles in the menu bar. After the manage styles window shows up, click the link style sheet button: From here you can navigate to your style sheet file and select ok. This will accomplish the same thing as dragging from the solution explorer.

The CSS Editor

The VWD CSS editor itself is pretty nice. It comes complete with the CSS Outline panel to get an overview of selectors and the CSS Properties panel to get a quick look at applied rules. The CSS editor also sports the intellisense we all know and love - that is code completion for properties and values.

Styling Our Page

We are going to style the page we created in the last entry. I am going to get some fonts and images from some good resources, and then apply the styles.

Using Google Web Fonts

I am going to use Google Web Fonts to add some typographic spice to my page. I love this service. You can choose your fonts, and Google will host the files and give you a link element to place in your document. Head over to Google Web Fonts and start shopping (for free). I chose the Lobster font for my headings (I know its overplayed, but man I love this font), and Droid Sans for the body copy. After choosing your fonts click that big 'ol "Use" button in the lower right: This will bring you to a page that lets you select the variants of each font that you want. I left the default. Once you are happy, go ahead and copy the text containing the link element and paste it into the head of your ASP document. The head of your document should have the following link elements: 
<link href='http://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Droid+Sans|Lobster' rel='stylesheet' type='text/css'>
<link href="styles.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
I am going to include some CSS in my attached style sheet to incorporate my new font styles: 
body 
{
    color:#444;
    font-family:"Droid Sans", Arial, Sans-Serif;
}
h1 
{
    color:#66c4ff;
    font-family:"Lobster",Helvetica,Arial, Sans-Serif;
    font-size:60px;
    font-weight:normal;
    text-shadow:0 1px 0px #fff;
}
p 
{
    text-shadow:0 1px 0px #fff;
}
With this we end up with the following: Still a little bland... we better add some background style.

Adding a Pattern from subtlepatterns.com

Head over to subtlepatterns.com to grab a slick background image. I snagged the Batthern pattern on page 4 of the site. Head over to VWD and right click the project name in the solution explorer and click "New Folder". Name it images. Drag the batthern.png file into this folder. Update the body selector in the style.css to look like this: 
body 
{
    background:#efefef url(images/batthern.png) repeat left top;
    color:#444;
    font-family:"Droid Sans", Arial, Sans-Serif;
}
Looking better:

Wrapping Up Our Style

Things look like they need to be centered. I am going to add an id attribute to the div element in the web form. The web form should look like this now: 
<form id="form1" runat="server">
<div id="wrapper">
    <h1>Web Forms Are Gnarly!</h1>
    <p>
        Hello <asp:Label runat="server" ID="lblName" />
    </p>
    <p>
        The date is currently <asp:Label runat="server" ID="lblDate" />
    </p>
</div>
</form>
Time to update the style sheet and add the wrapper selector and rules to center things: 
#wrapper
{
    margin:0 auto;
    padding:90px 10px 0 10px;
    text-align:center;
    width:940px;
}
And voila!

Conclusion

Adding styles can be very easy in ASP.NET. In my opinion it can also be unnecessarily cumbersome. I didn't cover "Build Styles" or "Add New Rule". These can be accessed along the tool bar in VWD, but in my opinion they are just a long route to the destination. The built in WYSIWYG functionality leaves a lot to be desired for a seasoned CSS veteran. Use the tools available to get a good overview of whats going on in the style landscape, but I wouldn't necessarily rely on them exclusively.
